title: Juul Is the Target of Another Investigation. What That Means For Altria Stock.
text:
Text size

Federal prosecutors in California joined a long list of regulators and political figures bearing down on Juul Labs. At first glance, that looks like bad news for Altria Group , which owns 35% of the maker of vaping products.

Yet the cigarette stock held its ground on Tuesday morning.

The back story. Altria (ticker: MO) spent $12.8 billion for its stake in Juul Labs last December. Many people saw the move as logical because the widespread view that e-cigarettes are safer than traditional ones has brought a surge in vaping, amid a decline in consumption of traditional cigarettes.

Still, the proliferation of e-cigarettes, both for tobacco and marijuana, among teenagers has brought concerns regarding federal regulation. More recently, a mysterious and sometimes fatal lung disease linked to vaping has put a spotlight on the industry.

Juul, a leading player in vaping, has come under particular scrutiny.

The company has noted its products don’t contain THC—the active ingredient in marijuana—or the vitamin E compounds apparently linked to these deaths. But President Donald Trump has said he hopes to ban non-tobacco vape flavors that have made it popular with non-smokers.

Analysts have speculated that the potential for regulation may have been a key factor behind Altria and Philip Morris International ’s (PM) decision to explore a merger.

What's new. The Wall Street Journal reported Monday night that the U.S. attorney’s office in the Northern District of California is in the early stages of a criminal investigation into Juul.

The Journal’s report didn’t specify the focus of the probe, but noted the company is facing several investigations of its marketing practices, given Juul products’ popularity among teenagers. The company declined to comment in the report, but has said it has never intended for youth to use its products.

“We have taken dramatic action to contribute to solve this problem, which is why we implemented the JUUL Labs Action Plan to address underage use of JUUL products,” the company said in December.

Despite the negative news, Altria shares were up 0.4% to $41.06, while Philip Morris stock was up 1.3% to $71.76. The Dow Jones Industrial Average has ticked up 30.11 points, or 0.1%, while the S&P 500 has advanced 0.1%.

Looking ahead. Wells Fargo Securities analyst Bonnie Herzog wrote in a note Tuesday morning that Juul would be an important part of the combined Philip Morris and Altria.

Herzog wrote, “we believe JUUL is a critical piece of the deal’s strategic rationale that increases MO’s attractiveness even in the current, admittedly tough, U.S. regulatory environment.”

Though regulatory pushback from Juul’s marketing practices could throw a wrench in this, Herzog wrote, “we doubt it would derail the companies’ plans.”

“In other words, we believe all of this risk would have been considered and, in our view, we think the companies view this risk as manageable,” Herzog added.

Write to Connor Smith at connor.smith@barrons.com
description: The Wall Street Journal reported that federal prosecutors in California are in the early stages of a criminal investigation of Juul, which is 35% owned by Altria.
